title: What is the original colour of water? If it is colourless, then how can we see it? - Quora

response.answer_text: We may not find ‘pure water’ in nature. The water we get to see around us contains dissolved chemicals and suspended matter. Water – even pure water – is not colourless. There is a hint of blue - easily observed when you look though a large amount of water – like in a swimming pool or a lagoon. Water molecules absorb the long waves of light – towards the red end of the spectrum – and hence the blueness. This is very well explained here. At best we can say that water is transparent – that is, it lets light pass through. You may ask then, “air is transparent too but we cannot see it”. We see water because the molecules absorb, refract and reflect light. In air, the nitrogen and oxygen gas molecules are spread far apart, (Density of water is 1000 kg/m³ and air is 1.225 kg/m³) so don't interact with light, letting it pass right through.

You can see water if the surface is open . This is due to reflection of light from the surface that is never steady due to microscopic ripples . If the water were to be very clean, filled in a plain glass vessel that is also very clean and plain, if the surface is not visible, you will not be able to make out whether there is water or not .
